questions.text: A patient presented with uveitis, enthesitis, and sacroiliitis. Which of the following is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features

General Features

Spine and Joint involvement

Extra-articular manifestations
  • Inflammatory back pain: Gradual onset, worse with inactivity, improves with movement and is often associated with early morning stiffness.
  • Fatigue: A common and significant symptom.
  • Postural changes: Loss of lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, and forward stooping of the neck.
  • Enthesitis: Inflammation at tendon or ligament attachment sites, often mistaken for fibromyalgia.
  • Peripheral joint involvement: Affects large joints like hips, knees, and shoulders and is usually asymmetrical.
  • Sacroiliac joint involvement: B/L and asymmetrical; pain may radiate to the buttocks or posterior thighs.
  • Reduced spinal mobility: Limited movement in the lumbar region due to inflammation and pain, often accompanied by muscle spasms.

 
  • Anterior uveitis: Most common extra articular manifestation. Presents with sudden unilateral eye pain, redness, and light sensitivity, often preceding joint symptoms.
  • Anaemia, prostatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, aortic valve disease, and very rare cases of amyloidosis or upper lobe pulmonary fibrosis
  • Osteoporosis: This can lead to vertebral fractures, especially with spinal fusion.

Investigations of Ankylosing Spondylitis

Tests

X-rays

MRI

  • HLA-B27: The presence of the HLA-B27 gene is a strong indicator of AS. The prevalence of AS in the general population is less than 0.5%.
  • Inflammatory Markers: Elevated ESR and CRP levels may indicate active disease.
  • Faecal Calprotectin: Helps screen for associated inflammatory bowel disease.

Show characteristic changes in sacroiliac joints, such as:

  • Blurred cortical margins
  • Erosions and sclerosis
  • "Pseudowidening" of joint space (early stages)
  • Joint space narrowing and fusion (later stages)
  • Bamboo spine - Vertebral body fusion by syndesmophytes
  • Dagger sign - Calcification appears as a single radiodense line vertically running down the spine on frontal radiographs.
  • Investigation of choice – more sensitive than X-rays for detecting early inflammatory changes.
  • Can reveal bone marrow oedema, enthesitis, synovitis, and erosions.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented with changes in the hand as shown below. There is decreased motion in the small joints and loss of wrinkle lines on the facial skin. Her chest radiograph showed prominent bilateral lower lobe infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which condition necessitates the use of anti-nuclear antibodies for accurate diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)

Definition

Chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organs and tissues.

Diagnostic Criteria

Presence of at least four of the following criteria, with at least one clinical and one immunologic criterion:
- Malar rash: "Butterfly" rash over the cheeks.
- Discoid rash: Red, raised patches with scaling.
- Photosensitivity: Skin rash after sun exposure.
- Oral ulcers: Painless ulcers in the mouth or nose.
- Arthritis: Non-erosive arthritis affecting two or more peripheral joints.
- Serositis: Pleuritis or pericarditis.
- Renal disorder: Proteinuria or cellular casts in urine.
- Neurologic disorder: Seizures or psychosis.
- Hematologic disorder: Hemolytic anemia, leukopenia, or lymphopenia.
- Immunologic disorder: Positive anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA) or other specific autoantibodies.
- Positive anti-dsDNA or anti-Smith antibodies.

Laboratory Tests

Complete blood count (CBC): May show anemia, leukopenia, or thrombocytopenia.
- Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP): Elevated markers of inflammation.
- Urinalysis: Proteinuria and cellular casts.
- Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA): Positive in most SLE cases.
- Anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith antibodies: Highly specific for SLE.
- Complement levels: May be decreased in active disease.

Additional Tests

Anti-phospholipid antibodies: Lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, or anti-beta-2 glycoprotein antibodies.
- Renal biopsy: May be performed to evaluate kidney involvement.
- Other imaging and organ-specific tests as needed for specific organ involvement.

Differential Diagnosis

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
- Sjögren's syndrome
- Systemic sclerosis
- Dermatomyositis
- Drug-induced lupus

Clinical Management

Individualized treatment based on disease severity and organ involvement.
- Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for mild arthritis and musculoskeletal symptoms.
- Corticosteroids: Prednisone is commonly used for moderate to severe disease.
- Immunosuppressants: Azathioprine, methotrexate, mycophenolate mofetil, or cyclophosphamide may be prescribed for refractory or organ-threatening disease.
- Hydroxychloroquine: Used for skin and joint manifestations.
- Patient education, counseling, and support.
- Regular monitoring and follow-up to assess disease activity and organ involvement.

  • Joint space narrowing, osteophytes, subchondral sclerosis, fractures, cortical thinning, osteosclerosis, lysis, pseudofractures, proliferative enthesis erosions, enthesophytes, joint deformity, subchondral cysts.
  • Heberden’s Nodes (involvement of DIP), Bouchard’s Nodes​ (involvement of PIP)

Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS)
  • Joint fusion, syndesmophytes, sacroiliitis, spinal ligament calcification.
  • Bamboo Spine, Shiny Corner Sign, Squaring of Vertebrae​

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
  • Joint space narrowing, periarticular osteoporosis, subchondral cysts, calcinosis cutis.
  • Destructive arthritis, erosions in later stages.

Gout
  • Acute inflammation, joint space narrowing, cortical erosions.
  • Tophus (urate crystal deposits in soft tissue).
  • Martel G sign: Also known as rat-bite erosions (lytic lesions with sclerotic margin & overhanging edge)

Scleroderma
  • Calcinosis cutis, soft tissue calcifications, joint space narrowing.
  • Ray Sign (involvement of small joints of hands).

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair. Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids was noted. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B- Dermatomyositis

Dermatomyositis

Definition

Dermatomyositis is a chronic, inflammatory myositis seen in adults around 50-60 years of age.

Clinical features

Clinical features

  • It presents as symmetrical muscle weakness (proximal > distal)
  • Gottron’s papules (erythematous scaly papules over knuckles) are pathognomonic of the disease.
  • Gottron’s sign: Symmetric, confluent, violaceous macular erythema (CMVE) on the back of fingers, on the extensor surfaces of joints of the elbows, knees, or ankles
  • CMVE is seen over other sites too, and is named accordingly.

 

  • Heliotrope rash: CMVE over the periorbital skin
  • V-Sign: CMVE over the anterior aspect of the neck
  • Shawl sign: Involvement of upper back
  • Holster sign: Rash over the lateral aspect of the thigh
  • Mechanic’s hand: Hyperkeratosis and fissuring on the edges of the fingers

questions.text: Takayasu arteritis most commonly involves:

An elderly woman presents with a chronic history of pain in the small joints of hands with stiffness of joints in the early hours of the day. The image of the patient's hands is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Rheumatoid Arth

Definition

Chronic autoimmune disease primarily affecting the joints, causing inflammation and joint damage.

Pathogenesis

Immune system attacks the synovium (lining of joints), leading to inflammation, joint swelling, and destruction.

Clinical Features

Joint pain, stiffness, and swelling, typically symmetrical and involving small joints of hands and feet.

Extra-Articular Manifestations

Rheumatoid nodules, lung involvement (interstitial lung disease), vasculitis, eye inflammation (scleritis), pericarditis.

Imaging

X-rays and MRI may show joint erosions, synovial hypertrophy, and soft tissue changes.

Laboratory Tests

Rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies are commonly measured. Elevated acute-phase reactants (e.g., CRP, ESR).

questions.text: Which of the following medications is not used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Febu

Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs)

Ibuprofen, Naproxen, Celecoxib

Inhibit the enzyme cyclooxygenase (COX), reducing the production of inflammatory prostaglandins. Provide pain relief and reduce inflammation.

Disease-Modifying Anti-rheumatic Drugs (DMARDs)

Methotrexate, Sulfasalazine, Leflunomide

Suppress the underlying immune response that drives inflammation in RA. Decrease the production of inflammatory cytokines and prevent joint damage.

Biologic DMARDs

Adalimumab, Etanercept, Infliximab

Target specific molecules involved in the immune response, such as tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha), interleukin-6 (IL-6), or B-lymphocyte stimulator (BLyS). Inhibit inflammatory processes and slow down joint damage.

Janus Kinase (JAK) Inhibitors

Tofacitinib, Baricitinib, Upadacitinib

Block the Janus kinase enzymes, which are involved in the signaling pathways of various cytokines. Reduce inflammation and joint damage by suppressing the immune response.

Corticosteroids

Prednisone, Methylprednisolone

Potent anti-inflammatory effects. Modulate immune responses, reduce inflammation, and provide rapid symptom relief.

Targeted Synthetic DMARDs

Tofacitinib, Baricitinib, Upadacitinib

Inhibit specific molecules within the immune system that contribute to RA, such as Janus kinase (JAK) enzymes. Reduce inflammation and joint damage.
